turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about SS Haiti (1932).
turn.1: What was the downgrading of the SS Haiti?
turn.2: Conversion of the ship to Navy requirements as prospective "Alameda" (AP-68) was cancelled when Navy found the ship unsuitable for the mission.
turn.3: What did they use it for instead?
turn.4: Other possibilities were explored, including conversion to a combined operations flagship, but those were abandoned and "Monterey" returned to Army support.
turn.5: When did it return to Army support?
turn.6: On 16 January the ship was delivered to the War Department for Army operation as USAT "Monterey".
turn.7: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.8: Army operations in the West Indies and South Atlantic had been hampered by port congestion and transportation problems at the base in Trinidad into the spring of 1943 when a new 1,202-foot Army wharf, port and railway equipment improved operations.
turn.10: Along with the improvements the Transportation Corps command at Trinidad was assigned the USAT "Monterey" for direct support of Trinidad and bases in the West Indies, at Ascension Island and in Brazil.
turn.11: Was it used for anything else after that?
turn.12: On 20 March 1946 the ship was again delivered to AGWI Lines for operation for WSA until laid up in the Reserve Fleet at Lee Hall, Virginia on 26 June and sale for $650,000 on 14 August 1947 to the Republic of with delivery to the buyer on 16 April 1948. The ship was renamed "Cankiri" and then "Adana" after sale.
